typography

Font

Xtyle uses the excellent Roboto font from Google as its default body font. You can change this option at any time on top of the xtyle.css file.

regular
thin
Strong
italic
links
marked
deleted
small
Small Caps
Xtyle uses <strong> and <em> to give emphasis to words and sentences. The <b> and <i> tags are used for design elements.

Headings

Use HTML heading tags between <h1> and <h6>.

Heading 1

Heading 2

Heading 3

Heading 4

Heading 5
Heading 6

Paragraphs

Paragraphs are defined using the <p> tag. Use paragraphs to separate your texts:

Proin tristique nunc enim, id scelerisque libero. Vestibulum viverra, tortor a vestibulum blandit, leo eros pellentesque mi, eu faucibus massa dolor ac lacus. Praesent et quam augue. In eget est nisi, et mattis ligula. Phasellus ut elit vel lorem faucibus molestie ac vehicula tortor.

Vivamus elementum tempus scelerisque. Maecenas id lectus orci, ut condimentum dui. Suspendisse eget dui eu nunc dignissim tincidunt at a massa. Phasellus feugiat fermentum adipiscing. Praesent pharetra ultrices sodales. Pellentesque sed diam nunc, sit amet auctor magna.

Drop Caps

To capitalize the first word of your paragraph you can use drop caps. You can define a drop caps using the <span class="drop-caps"> tag inside a paragraph:

Proin eu erat nunc, id viverra urna. Donec id quam ac lacus ultrices commodo quis id elit. Sed vitae diam nulla, ac convallis lacus. Nunc eu sapien quis tortor tempor ornare non eget massa. Nulla in eros odio, sed congue mi. Curabitur suscipit pulvinar hendrerit. Maecenas vestibulum nibh non erat auctor accumsan porta erat commodo.

Blockquotes

Write quotes using the <blockquote> tag. Use paragraphs <p> inside blockquotes to write content on it. You can also include the source of your quote using the optional <cite> tag:

"A blockquote."

"With citation."

– by xchema
Colors:

"Inverse"

"Warning"

"Error"

"Info"

"Success"

List styles

You can make your lists using the <ul> for unordered lists, <ol> for ordered lists, and <dt> for definition lists. Use <ul class="reset"> to remove styles from lists.

Unordered list:
  • Apples
    • Aceymac
    • Adanac
  • Oranges
Unordered list (reset):
  • Apples
    • Aceymac
    • Adanac
  • Oranges
Ordered list:
  1. Apple
    • Aceymac
    • Adanac
  2. Orange
Definition list:
Apples
Aceymac
Adanac
Oranges
Inline list:
  • Apples
  • Oranges

Addresses

The <address> element is used to provide contact information. Use <abbr> to write abbreviations:

xchema

South Whisman Road
Mountain View, CA 94041
United States
+1 (123) 456-7890

Alerts

Alerts are the easiest way to drive attention to important content. Use the tag <alert> with the classes .warning (default), .error, .info, and .success:

Warning!Use this tag for items that require attention.

Alert!Use this tag when something goes wrong.

Information!Use this tag to provide important information.

Success!Use this tag when some task or action end successfuly.

Tags

Tags are small hints about the subject of an article or blog post. You can express a tag using the tag element.

Regular tag Attention tag Alert Information Success

Tables

Use tables to organize data information as such financial reports for example. Use <table> tag to declare a table, <tr> for rows, and <td> for columns.

Fruits
Apples
Oranges
Hover rows:

You can have an hover effect adding the class .hover to your <table> tag. Add the class.pointer to turn the cursor into the pointer type if you want to.

Fruits
Apples
Oranges
Grapes
Bananas
Striped rows:

You can create stripe rows adding the class .stripes to your <table> tag.

Fruits
Apples
Oranges
Grapes
Bananas
Color rows:

You can highlight rows using the same classes available for alerts .warning, .error, .info, and .success:

Colors
Regular
Attention
Alert
Info
